origination.corpname: University of Michigan. English Language Institute.

did.unittitle: English Language Institute (University of Michigan), records 1940-2004
did.abstract: University of Michigan department responsible in part for the development of materials for the teaching of English as a second language. The English Language Institute records contain correspondence, notes from staff meetings, printed materials, reports, photographs, and administrative records, especially records of South East Asia Regional English Program and the Ford-Japan Project. The records also include files of directors Charles C. Fries and Robert Lado and administrator George E. Luther. Also includes photos of institute staff, students, and activities, including foreign students at the University of Michigan and the institute's South East Asia Regional English Project (1957-1965).

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The records of the English Language Institute (Donor Nos. 3349 and 7050) were first donated in 1984. Additions to the collection were given in December 1999 and March 2004

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, English Language Institute (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The English Language Institute (ELI) was founded by Charles C. Fries in 1941 as the first full-time intensive English Language Institute in the United States, and was in the forefront of English as a Second Language (ESL) teaching and ESL teacher training. ELI's special interest and involvement in language testing began more than fifty years ago with the work of Robert Lado. Since the early 1950s, ELI has been developing and administering various language tests, some designed for use within the University of Michigan and others for use nationally and internationally. By the late 1950s the ELI had international language programs in countries on five continents. One of the most extensive was the Southeast Asian Regional English Project (SEAREP), with a budget of nearly two million dollars under contract to the United States Agency for International Development (AID). During the 1960s and 70s, ELI developed experimental teaching methods, materials, and teacher training programs to aid in the teaching of English as a second or foreign language. Large-scale research and development of teaching materials including textbooks and audio-tapes were produced and marketed through the University of Michigan Press.

In 1986, the ELI adopted a new mission: to provide a full range of courses in English for Academic Purposes (EAP) for non-native speaking students, staff, visiting scholars, and faculty at the University of Michigan and to carry out relevant research. The new courses were designed to help non-native speakers enhance their linguistic and communicative skills to become effective, fully participating members of the academic community both during their campus career and beyond. In support of this new mission in the university, the ELI has engaged in research and development across a number of key areas, including ESP instruction and particularly task-based instruction, applied to discourse analysis, language assessment, applications of audio and video technology within language instruction, and adult second language acquisition.

At present ELI has forged links with the world, providing research facilities and consultation for visiting scholars from China, Tadzhikistan, South Africa, Sweden, and Brazil, to name a few. The Morley Scholarship Fund, established under director John Swales, has provided financial support for several researchers. The testing program has also expanded from two to three overseas testing operations, and on campus the ELI offers thirty courses at the graduate and undergraduate level for students, researchers, visiting scholars, and university staff in a variety of subjects. Other offerings include International Graduate Student Instructor spring and summer workshops for LS&A and Engineering, speaking and writing clinics, and pre-sessional summer programs in EAP: English for Business Studies, and English for Legal Studies. The ELI website can be found at: http://www.lsa.umich.edu/eli/.

chronitem.event: A.H. Marckwardt, Acting Director and Director
John Swales, Acting Director and Director

scopecontent.p: The records of the English Language Institute of The University of Michigan encompass the period, 1940-2004, and contain 11 series: Correspondence; C.C. Fries Correspondence; Books; Manuscripts and Publications; Scrapbooks; Project Files; Administrative Files; South East Asia Regional English Project (SEAREP); Ford-Japan Project; Publications; and Photographs. The bulk of the collection deals with routine business such as student requests for admission, inquiries from throughout the world regarding the operation of the Institute, requests for linguistic materials available from the Institute, and staff meeting minutes. There is an abundance of information on the relationship between the English Language Institute, its staff and similar institutions both at the University of Michigan and elsewhere; including the University of Michigan International Center, the Civil Aeronautics Administration, the English Language Institute in Mexico, the Ford Foundation, the Inter-American Educational Foundation, the Kellogg Foundation, the Linguistic Institute, Rockefeller Foundation, and the U.S. Office of Education. Also in the collection are extensive files of directors Charles C. Fries and Robert Lado and administrator George E. Luther.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1941-1957, 4 linear ft.) is mostly arranged topically and then chronologically within each folder. Corespondents include: James P. Adams, Edward M. Anthony, Samuel T. Dana, Olcott T. Deming, Claude A. Eggertsen, Warren E. Forsythe, Esson M. Gale, Otto G. Graf, Hayward Keniston, Hans Kurath, Albert H. Marckwardt, William F. Marquardt, Ralph A Sawyer, Leonard A. Schaadt, Yao Shen, Francis C. Shiel, Aileen Traver, Mildred L. Tuttle, and Clarence S. Yoakum.

scopecontent.p: The C.C. Fries Correspondence series (1940-1957, 1 linear ft.) contains the correspondence of ELI founder and director, Charles Carpenter Fries. Files are arranged chronologically and include both ingoing and outgoing correspondence.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with and donations to the C.C. Fries Fund Committee 1957

scopecontent.p: The Books (1944-1956, 1 linear ft.) in the ELI records serve as English language teaching materials for Latin American and Chinese students, and also include Patterns of English Sentences and Lessons in Pronunciation.

scopecontent.p: The Manuscripts of Publications series (undated, .5 linear ft.) include several copies of An Intensive Course in English for Latin American Students

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks series (1941-1966, .5 linear ft.) includes two scrapbooks with photographs.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook of Professor and Mrs. Leo Rockwell circa 1941-1966

scopecontent.p: The Project Files (1952-1976, 2 linear ft.) contain various records of programs and projects run by the ELI. Examples include several overseas projects (SEAREP, Pakistan Project, etc.), the Robert Lado Project File, and the Teachers Education Project.

did.unittitle: South East Asian Regional English Project (SEAREP) 1957-1965
South East Asian Regional English Project (SEAREP) 1957-1965 (cont.)

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files (1952-2005, 1.5 linear ft.) include records relating to the internal operation of ELI. The series contains a great deal of various meeting minutes, reports, agendas, and vision statements, and also represented are ELI anniversary celebrations, budgets, correspondence, and student statistics.

did.unittitle: Internal Report of English Language Institute 1999
South East Asia Regional English Project (SEAREP) 1958-1964

scopecontent.p: The South East Asia Regional English Project (SEAREP) (1958-1964, 6.5 linear ft.) contains records from one of ELI's most extensive international language programs. Two subseries are present. The Campus Coordinator Office subseries primarily contains files on the administrative side of the project with personnel and correspondence. The Project Office subseries focuses more on the project in action with proposals, reports, and materials from the various South East Asian countries involved, including Burma, Cambodia, Laos, Indonesia, Vietnam and Thailand.

did.unittitle: Hatcher visit to South East Asia
Special Course for Teachers of English
Department of Teacher Training counterpart funds
United States. Agency for International Development
United States Operations Mission to Thailand (USOM)

scopecontent.p: The Ford-Japan Project series (1959-1964, .7 linear ft.) represents another ELI language program in conjunction with Japanese universities and the Ford Foundation. The series includes correspondence, project reports and proposals, scholarships, and files on several Japanese universities.

did.unittitle: Advisory Committee on the Training of Teachers of English in Selected Japanese Universities (ACTT) 1959-1964
Kobe City University of Foreign Studies
University of Tokyo. Faculty of Letters

scopecontent.p: The Publications series (1941-2003, .3 linear ft.) contains items published by the ELI including early student publications, brochures, teaching materials, and newsletters.

did.unittitle: ELI Publication Lists, Promotional Materials, and Brochures, undated 1973-2003

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series contains (undated, .3 linear ft.) photographs, ca.1940-1970, relating to the activities of the English Language Institute. The series includes pictures of instruction, conferences, visitors, faculty, foreign students and social activities.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers interested in the English Language Institute Records may also be interested in the Ruth Hok Papers at the Bentley Historical Library, the Coordinator's report: International teachers of English, Fall 1954, and various serials also held at the Bentley: The Ann Arbor Diary, Language and Learning, International Teachers of English-English Language Institute, and English language institute at the University of Michigan for Latin-American students and teachers of English. The journal Language and Learning is also in the holdings of the Hatcher Graduate Library and the Shapiro Undergraduate Library. Also of interest at the Bentley are: Lessons in pronunciation by the research staff of the English Language Institute and the publication, Intensive Course in English for Latin American students (call no.: FImu B27 .E58 A4).
